Lesson 20 – Trennbare Verbs & Irregular Verbs

We are good with regular verbs like:
ich trinke, du trinkst, er trinkt, wir trinken, sie trinken.
We also know some irregular verbs like haben and sein.
In this lesson, we will look at more irregular verbs, including trennbare Verben (separable verbs) which many learners find tricky.

Irregular Verbs that Change for Pronunciation

Some verbs are irregular because following the regular pattern makes them hard to pronounce.
Example: arbeiten or finden.
If we write du arbeitst or er arbeitt, it's hard to pronounce, so German adds extra letters:

  • ich arbeite
  • du arbeitest
  • er arbeitet
  • wir arbeiten
  • sie arbeiten
Same with finden.
Rule: If a verb stem (infinitive minus -en) ends with t or d, be careful when conjugating, as extra letters may be added for pronunciation.

10 Important Irregular Verbs to Remember

Some common verbs change in the du and er/sie/es forms.
For some, the er form is just the du form without the -st ending.
Infinitiveduer/sie/es
sehensiehstsieht
fahrenfährstfährt
helfenhilfsthilft
gebengibstgibt
nehmennimmstnimmt
sprechensprichstspricht

schlafenschläfstschläft
lesenliestliest

Introduction to Trennbare Verben (Separable Verbs)

German often creates new verbs by adding prefixes like auf, an, aus.
But, just like 'understand' in English doesn't literally mean 'stand under', aufwachen doesn't mean 'on guard'.
Common prefixes:

  • auf
  • an
  • ab
  • aus
  • bei
  • ein
  • los
  • mit
  • nach
  • hin
  • her
  • vor
  • weg
  • zu
  • zurück
When conjugated in a sentence, these verbs split apart – we’ll see how next!

Some Trennbare Verbs & Meanings

  • anmachen – to switch on
  • ausmachen – to switch off
  • zumachen – to close
  • aufmachen – to open
  • aufwachen – to wake up
Golden Rule 1: Never translate trennbare verbs literally! Learn their real meaning as vocabulary.

Golden Rule 2 – Prefix Moves to the End

When you conjugate a trennbare verb in simple tense, the prefix moves to the end.
aufwachen (to wake up):
Ich wache auf
Du wachst auf
Er wacht auf
Wir wachen auf
Sie wachen auf

Examples:
We wake up at 8 – Wir wachen um 8 auf.
He opens the window – Er macht das Fenster auf.
I switch off the radio – Ich mache das Radio aus.

Golden Rule 3 – Modal Verbs with Trennbare Verbs

When a modal verb is in the sentence, the modal verb is conjugated and the trennbare verb moves to the end in its infinitive form (stays joined together).
Example:
We switch the radio off – Wir machen das Radio aus.
We can switch the radio off – Wir können das Radio ausmachen.
Notice: 'ausmachen' stays together at the end, because 'können' is conjugated.

Summary – Irregular & Trennbare Verbs

Irregular Verbs: Some change spelling for easier pronunciation (arbeiteten, fanden). Others change their vowels in 'du' and 'er' forms (sehen – siehst/sieht).
Trennbare Verben – 3 Golden Rules:

  • Golden Rule 1: Never translate literally – learn meaning as vocabulary.
  • Golden Rule 2: In simple tenses, the prefix moves to the end.
  • Golden Rule 3: With modal verbs, the prefix stays attached at the end in infinitive form.
Practice both simple and modal verb sentences to master their use!
